work.name: Deep Genomics, Target & Systems Biology
highlights: Conducted a literature review on knowledge graph methodologies and use cases to identify high-impact integration opportunities within the target discovery pipeline, resulting in stakeholder buy-in for a proposed minimal implementation project.

Preprocessed biomedical data from public sources using Python, then imported and structured the data in Neo4j to build a disease-specific knowledge graph composed of more than 34K nodes and 270K edges.

Implemented a metapath-based approach to identify gene-disease associations and then presented findings to senior leadership, securing approval to scale the project into a larger graph integrating internal and public data.
Defining the schema for a larger pilot knowledge graph and identifying publicly available multi-omics data sources and biomedical ontologies with permissive licenses.
Preprocessing proprietary data and mapping biological entities to stable identifiers, enabling their inclusion in the pilot knowledge graph.

work.name: Princess Margaret Cancer Centre, Kridel Lab
highlights: Applied dimensionality reduction techniques (PCA and NMF) in R to explore cfMeDIP- seq fragmentation data, identifying the most distinguishing features for further analysis.
Trained a KNN classifier to distinguish lymphoma cases from healthy controls, exploring the utility of using pooled cfDNA fragmentation profiles as diagnostic biomarkers.
Developed and documented Unix shell scripts for reproducible data preprocessing on HPC clusters, enabling robust analysis and ensuring smooth project handover.

Presented research findings through weekly lab meetings, written reports, and a poster at Cancer 360+ Research Day, effectively communicating results to PI, peers, collaborators, and other student researchers.
Engaged in journal clubs and research progress meetings, staying current with lymphoma genomics literature and providing constructive feedback on experimental approaches and data analysis.

work.name: University of Toronto, Osmond Lab
highlights: Executed simulations of diploid genome evolution using the SLiM framework, scripting in Python and Unix to automate data extraction and visualize coalescent trees.
Proposed and led a collaborative project to develop a tree visualization tutorial for population genetics researchers, published on GitHub to promote open-access learning.
